stimulusHtml:
Respond to parts A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and all subparts.

(a) Describe one negative human health effect associated with urbanization.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml: (b) Describe TWO environmental benefits of urbanization.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml:
Geographic features and climatological factors can make some locations more prone to the effects of air pollution. The diagram below illustrates a city of millions of people and its surrounding geography. Human activities in urban areas can release pollutants into the air that lead to ground-level ozone and smog formation.

(c) Describe how a thermal inversion would form in the city shown in the diagram.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml: (d) Describe the relationship between a thermal inversion and pollution.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml: (e) Explain how one factor related to climate could make the city shown in the diagram susceptible to prolonged periods of ground-level ozone and smog.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml: (f) Explain how a geographical feature could make the city shown in the diagram susceptible to prolonged periods of ground-level ozone and smog.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml: (g) Propose a solution to reduce the formation of ground-level ozone or smog resulting from human activities in the city.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml:
(h) Air pollution such as smog and ground-level ozone are not the only problems associated with urbanization. Human-made structures in urban areas can increase the amount of runoff reaching streams and lakes.

(i) Propose a solution to reduce the effects of urban runoff.

features.html:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

As the human population grows, more individuals are moving into urban areas.

stimulusHtml: (ii) Justify the solution proposed in (h)(i) by describing an additional benefit, other than reducing the effects of urban runoff.
